awd_abstract_narration:
Conformal maps are functions or transformations of space that, locally, preserve angles. The study of the geometric properties of such maps has led to the development of Geometric Function Theory and has proven over the years to be of fundamental importance to a wide variety of problems in analysis, geometry, probability, physics, and engineering. More recently, much attention has been devoted to the study of maps, or functions, that are a generalization of conformal maps, called of quasiconformal maps, where a controlled amount of angle distortion is allowed. Quasiconformal mappings possess subtle properties, making them very useful in a wide variety of settings. In many of these applications, one must deal with maps that are (quasi)conformal in a given planar region except possibly for some “exceptional set” of points inside the region. The question whether the exceptional set is negligible and small enough to be ignored leads to the notion of conformal removability, central to this research project and closely related to fundamental questions in complex analysis and other areas. The principal investigator has no doubt that many more fruitful connections should come to light as progress is made toward a better understanding of removability. This project will also consider several other problems in Geometric Function Theory, some with applications in the field of numerical vision. An important portion of the proposed research involves numerical computations and constructive methods. In addition to enhancing computational infrastructure, this has the potential to build interdisciplinary connections.
 
The first proposed activity deals with the study of the relationship between removability and the rigidity of circle domains in Koebe’s uniformization conjecture, building upon the pioneering work of He and Schramm. The principal investigator plans to pursue the study of this surprising connection. The second proposed activity is devoted to the study of conformal welding. The principal investigator proposes to work on several constructive aspects as well as on the relationship between the non-injectivity of conformal welding and removability. Finally, the third proposed activity involves the study of the properties of analytic capacity. The principal investigator first suggests to further investigate the subadditivity of analytic capacity. This part of the proposal involves numerical computations using a program developed by the principal investigator together with an undergraduate student. The principal investigator also plans to study the behavior of analytic capacity under holomorphic motions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The main objective of the project was the development of new techniques for the study of conformal and quasiconformal mappings. Conformal maps are transformations of the plane that locally preserve angles. Quasiconformal mappings, on the other hand, allow for a controlled amount of angle distortion, making them a generalization of conformal maps that are very useful in a wide variety of areas of mathematics, from complex analysis, holomorphic dynamics,Teichmuller theory, quadratic differentials and Kleinian groups, to harmonic analysis, partial differential equations, singular integral operators, inverse problems and calculus of variations. Another focus of the project was on the study of certain families of quasiconformal mappings called holomorphic motions. The principal investigator aimed to study how certain quantities such as analytic capacity and continuous analytic capacity change under holomorphic motions.

 

- Intellectual Merit:

During the project, new analytic methods have been developed. The PI and his collaborators obtained several geometric and analytic characterizations of certain fractal curves called 'purely unrectifiable quasicircles'. These results led to a better understanding of the geometric properties of quasiconformal mappings. 

In another line of research, the PI and his collaborators described the variation of several quantities such as area, capacity and dimension under holomorphic motions. This led to a unified treatment of several celebrated theorems about quasiconformal mappings, and many more fruitful connections are anticipated as progress continues to be made towards a better understanding of holomorphic motions.

- Broader Impact:

One of the main goals of the project was to improve STEM education and contribute to the development of a diverse, globally competitive STEM workforce. In this direction, the PI mentored one postdoctoral researcher and is currently mentoring three Ph.D. students. The PI has also been co-organizing the Mathematics Professional Development Seminar at the University of Hawaii, whose goal is to help graduate students and postdocs regarding various aspects of their professional development in mathematics, including NSF fellowship/grant applications,transition from mathematics to industry, job applications (research and teaching). In addition, the PI gave several graduate topics courses and organized various study seminars and workshops.

 

 


Last Modified: 08/05/2024
Modified by: Malik Younsi
